title: RIOT WATCH THE UOL VS FNC GAME
body:
And see why your LC$BIGPLAY$ Lee Sin philosophy can go to hell.  

This is why I watch LCS games.  this right here, and you had Season 2 mobility on display in the game.

replies.body:
Could not agree more. The game had absolutely everything that makes me go "wow" in a game: incredible engages, immense crowd control, the constant threat of massive burst from so many people, the consistent thought of "CAN CASS DO IT IN THIS FIGHT?" while you watch her melting people, and at the core of it, *the recognition that there was counterplay to literally everything*. Everyone could engage on each other, there were no sure thing get out of jail free cards, there was risk and reward.

You know what Lee Sin would have been doing in every team fight in that game? Trying to poke with Q and Safeguarding, maybe hitting R on whoever gets too close to him. You know what he wouldn't have brought? Literally all of the excitement I just listed. I find it hilarious to say that Lee Sin, posterboy of LC$BIGPLAY$, would have quite honestly massively reduced my enjoyment of that game.

See, you can describe Lee Sin and Zed as "flashy" and "intensive" champions, but despite Yorick's faceroll nature and overall low mobility of most champions (save for LeBlanc), this game was more intense than a mirror Zed matchup.

I think the highlight of the game was using the Omen of Death to allow Nunu to consume+Smite the Baron despite getting focused and killed. That game was all about DECISIONS, not ACTIONS. And speaking of decisions, you can argue about stuff like "Sejuani should have built more MR to survive Cassio's damage instead of redundant Sunfire components" instead of "Well they should have flashed from that insec kick".

Yorick.

Nunu.

Cassio.

Caitlyn.

Annie.

If actions speak louder than words, why is it, when the 2 contradict, everyone always comes back to what I *say*.  Look at what Riot says, and what they do.  Morello himself is recently quoted as having said "Lee Sin shits on everyone, and he probably shouldn't (sic)."  Yet, 2 patches have come and gone, and no changes to Lee Sin's kit to reduce his feces based lane phase.  The forum assigned the Lee Sin Big Play syndrome because it's the communities only explanation for what's going on.  Because it seems clear that twitch reflex skill based champions are being treated with a different philosophy than their slower sustained dps counterparts.  Veigar was a clear message, and shots fired across the bow.  

If you aren't capable of seeing it, that's your problem.  Not mine.

>Because it seems clear that twitch reflex skill based champions are being treated with a different philosophy than their slower sustained dps counterparts.

It's not all bad though - even if they aren't getting shut down, we ARE seeing some of the diversity Riot preached about at the start of the season, even if the unjustifiable death of entire playstyles is somehow necessary for it.  I'm finding that the jungle is enjoyable again thanks to this patch, and while I don't play Veigar, I hope they can fix his stun.  That change and the reasoning they gave was just awful, and they should know better than this. 

But back to positives, we're starting to see diversity in other areas now that the balance team has pulled their heads out of their asses and finally did what we've been telling them to do for god knows how long, and tanks are now back - that's great, thank you!  However, the thought remains; how long will this last before they come to the unanimous, non-community interactive decision that tanks are still boring and gut them to allow flashy playmakers back onto the throne? 

Maybe I'm being too pessimistic about this, but can I be blamed for it?  I'll enjoy this patch for as long as I can because for the time being, it seems Riot is beginning to understand  how fucking agonizing this mobility meta is for everyone but flashy playmakers and all of you filthy Kalista, Lee, and Nidalee mains.

I honestly would have to strongly disagree, with immobility, you need to commit 100% to a fight, every fight. When there's mobility thrown into the mix, the ability to disengage just becomes too easy and most fights will end in stalemate of no one dying.

On UoL's team, they had one person with a dash, and that was Caitlyn. With an immobile comp, it becomes a do or die fight every time. And that's exactly what happened here. Yes, there were mistakes made and poor calls and throws on both sides, but what it comes down to though is the nature of the comp UoL which forced a 100% commitment from any fight. 

This is why mobility lacks excitement now...yes it can be exciting to see people flying around the map, but the ability to avoid a fight you know you're going to lose becomes increasingly easier, which leads to games being a bore to watch. I will always take watching a fight ending in both teams steam rolling each other then one team setting up a flashy play to take one person out then running away. 

I will agree though that your description fits exactly how Riot sees the game at the current moment.

>On UoL's team, they had one person with a dash, and that was Caitlyn. With an immobile comp, it becomes a do or die fight every time. And that's exactly what happened here. Yes, there were mistakes made and poor calls and throws on both sides, but what it comes down to though is the nature of the comp UoL which forced a 100% commitment from any fight.

Personally, I'd like to see more of this.  It's exciting to see constant fights and commitment to a fight you cant escape from.  Play becomes more decision based than reaction based.  

Lee is about to dive into 3 people alone?  It's okay, he'll safeguard out.  LB didn't get a kill?  Press W again.  Zed is in a bad position?  He can shadow dash away.  Kalista is in a tricky spot?  Doesn't matter because she has a dash on every single auto attack.  

Nunu can't leave the teamfight, Yorick is...Yorick - he doesn't do a whole lot of anything, Nautilus needs a clear shot to terrain to make an escape, but even then, he's so slow, etc.  Everything has to be thought out beforehand rather than reacting to what happens faster than the other person, and that's the direction I think Riot should be taking for League.
